subject: Software Quality Assurance and Testing - Lecture 1
topic: Fundamentals of Software Testing & Bug Life Cycle

questions.question: What is the primary definition of Software Testing?
options: The process of writing code for the application
The process of executing a program with the intent of finding errors
The process of designing the user interface
The process of fixing bugs found by users
questions.correct_answer: The process of executing a program with the intent of finding errors

questions.question: Which of the following statements about testing limitations is true? [cite: 4]
options: Testing can prove the absence of bugs
It is possible to completely test any non-trivial system
Testing can only show the presence of bugs, not their absence
questions.correct_answer: Testing can only show the presence of bugs, not their absence

questions.question: What is the difference between Verification and Validation? [cite: 8]
options: Verification asks 'Are we building the right product?'; Validation asks 'Are we building the product right?'
Verification asks 'Are we building the product right?'; Validation asks 'Are we building the right product?'
Verification is manual; Validation is automated
Verification is done by users; Validation is done by developers
questions.correct_answer: Verification asks 'Are we building the product right?'; Validation asks 'Are we building the right product?'

questions.question: Which fault handling technique involves 'Reviews' and 'Configuration Management'? [cite: 5]
questions.correct_answer: Fault Avoidance

questions.question: What is Black-Box Testing? [cite: 18]
options: Testing with full knowledge of the internal structure and code
Testing where the internal structure/design/implementation is not known to the tester
questions.correct_answer: Testing where the internal structure/design/implementation is not known to the tester

questions.question: What is White-Box Testing? [cite: 21]
options: Testing based on analysis of the internal structure of the component or system
Testing based solely on requirements documents
Testing without looking at the code
questions.correct_answer: Testing based on analysis of the internal structure of the component or system

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of Functional Testing? [cite: 13]
questions.correct_answer: Unit Testing

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of Non-Functional Testing? [cite: 15]
questions.correct_answer: Performance Testing

questions.question: What is 'Smoke Testing'?
options: Testing the application under heavy load
Detailed testing of a specific feature
A subset of test cases to ensure the most critical functions work (General Health Checkup)
Testing done by the developer before checking in code
questions.correct_answer: A subset of test cases to ensure the most critical functions work (General Health Checkup)

questions.question: When is 'Sanity Testing' performed?
options: Before the build is released to QA
After receiving a software build with minor changes in code or functionality
questions.correct_answer: After receiving a software build with minor changes in code or functionality

questions.question: What is the main goal of 'Regression Testing'?
options: To check if the new code has broken existing functionality
To test the user interface design
questions.correct_answer: To check if the new code has broken existing functionality

questions.question: Which testing type is also known as 'Glass Box' or 'Clear Box' testing? [cite: 21]
questions.correct_answer: White-Box Testing

questions.question: What is a 'Defect' or 'Bug'? [cite: 55]
options: A mistake made by the developer
The mechanical or algorithmic cause of an error
A deviation of the observed behavior from the specified behavior
questions.correct_answer: The mechanical or algorithmic cause of an error

questions.question: What is an 'Error' in testing terminology? [cite: 55]
options: The system is in a state such that further processing will lead to a failure
questions.correct_answer: The system is in a state such that further processing will lead to a failure

questions.question: What is a 'Failure'? [cite: 55]
options: A human action that produces an incorrect result
Any deviation of the observed behavior from the specified behavior
questions.correct_answer: Any deviation of the observed behavior from the specified behavior

questions.question: According to the lecture, who tests the software 'gently' and is driven by 'delivery'? [cite: 57]
questions.correct_answer: The Developer

questions.question: What drives the 'Independent Tester'? [cite: 57]
options: Quality and attempting to break the system
questions.correct_answer: Quality and attempting to break the system

questions.question: What is the cost of fixing a bug found in the Maintenance phase compared to the Requirements phase? [cite: 10]
options: It is significantly more expensive (up to 100x)
questions.correct_answer: It is significantly more expensive (up to 100x)

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a level of testing? [cite: 11]
questions.correct_answer: Marketing Testing

questions.question: What is 'Static Testing'? [cite: 17]
options: Testing without executing the program (e.g., reviews, inspections)
questions.correct_answer: Testing without executing the program (e.g., reviews, inspections)

questions.question: What does 'Dynamic Testing' involve? [cite: 17]
options: Executing the program with input data
questions.correct_answer: Executing the program with input data

questions.question: In the Bug Life Cycle, what status is assigned when a bug is first logged? [cite: 44]
questions.correct_answer: New

questions.question: What status does a bug get when a developer accepts it and starts working on it? [cite: 44]
questions.correct_answer: Open

questions.question: If a developer thinks a reported bug is not a genuine defect, what status might they assign? [cite: 44]
questions.correct_answer: Rejected

questions.question: What does the 'Deferred' status mean in the Bug Life Cycle? [cite: 44]
options: The bug is fixed but not verified
The bug is expected to be fixed in the next release (low priority)
The bug already exists in the database
questions.correct_answer: The bug is expected to be fixed in the next release (low priority)

questions.question: Which component of a Bug Report describes 'How to reproduce the bug'? [cite: 49]
questions.correct_answer: Steps to Reproduce

questions.question: What defines 'Severity' in a bug report? [cite: 52]
options: How quickly the bug must be fixed
The impact of the bug on the application's functionality
The time taken to fix the bug
questions.correct_answer: The impact of the bug on the application's functionality

questions.question: What defines 'Priority' in a bug report? [cite: 52]
options: The order in which the bug should be fixed
The damage caused to the system
The technical difficulty of the fix
questions.correct_answer: The order in which the bug should be fixed

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an 'Algorithmic Fault'? [cite: 56]
options: Documentation does not match actual conditions
Mismatch between client needs and server offers
questions.correct_answer: Missing initialization or branching errors

questions.question: What type of error includes 'Stress or overload errors'? [cite: 56]
questions.correct_answer: Capacity or boundary errors

questions.question: Sanity Testing is a subset of which testing type? [cite: 32]
questions.correct_answer: Regression Testing

questions.question: What is the key difference between Smoke and Sanity testing? [cite: 34]
options: Smoke verifies critical functionalities; Sanity verifies specific functionality changes
Smoke is done by testers; Sanity is done by developers
Smoke is narrow and deep; Sanity is wide and shallow
Smoke is done on stable builds; Sanity is done on unstable builds
questions.correct_answer: Smoke verifies critical functionalities; Sanity verifies specific functionality changes

questions.question: Which status indicates that the tester has verified the fix and the bug no longer exists? [cite: 44]
questions.correct_answer: Closed

questions.question: What is 'Retest' in the Bug Life Cycle? [cite: 44]
options: The developer is fixing the bug again
The tester is verifying the fix provided by the developer
The manager is reviewing the bug
The bug is sent back to the developer
questions.correct_answer: The tester is verifying the fix provided by the developer

questions.question: Which testing type involves checking the system against the Requirements Specification? [cite: 13]
questions.correct_answer: System Testing
